On time. Pretty great condition. I love physics so much. I haven't read it all but so far its pretty awesome
ok
I want to read all of his books and I'm not even good at science

I have two paperback books from the publisher "Vintage". Both fell apart. We all want cheaper books, but cutting corners to the point where they fall apart by just opening them MIGHT BE GOING TOO FAR!
He takes difficult concepts and makes them understandable.I not only enjoyed this book,I learned a lot.In fact,I could not put it down and I plan to reread it. Good Job.
This is a very great book. I highly recommend it. It covers a great many things and explains them as clearly as possible.
As a former researcher myself, I just couldn't deal with the layer upon layer of speculation - even though it is interesting speculation.
A great read.

The book was delivered in great condition, a few minor spots on the paper cover but nothing that can take away from reading the book!  The content within the book is also very thought provoking, I would recommend it to anyone with a deep interest in space/time topics.

Just finished the book. I've read the "Elegant Universe" and "Black Holes and Time Warps" and I thought this book was somewhat of a rehash of the two. Although many of the analogies he presented were very clear, I think he went overboard in some areas. It probably could have been a 300 page book.
I bought the audio and listened to it.  It was very informative but it did a bit dry from time to time but still good to listen to.
Enjoyed this audiobook so much I bought elegant universe.  They are a bit light on the math but I suppose that sells.

Like many other readers of The Fabric of the Cosmos, who thought of this book as a "sequel" to The Elegant Universe, I was disappointed. Personally, I liked the first chapter, where he discusses the point of view of many physicists, like Newton, Mach and Einstein. The first half of this book is based on well-established physical theories (particularly, Quantum Mechanics and Special/General Relativity, which, by the way, have already been experimentally tested many times).  BUT, he spent (or wasted) the second part of his book on speculations on String/M theory, and, OK, we understand Grenne is a string physicist, but it seems he forgets that UNTIL TODAY, THERE IS NO EXPERIMENTAL PROOF SUPPORTING STRING THEORY (or Higgs Field, Braneworlds, wormholes, etc). So it IS senseless to speculate about a speculative theory, or even worse, to try to get conclusions about our reality from it. The author tends to sell phrases such as "many researchers think that..." (with no references at all), which are written just to overweigh the real content of his arguments. I agree with other reviewers: his pop-culture analogies just insult the inteligence of the readers. To the readers who were disappointed by this childish book, I would recommend to them DEL MUNDO CUÁNTICO AL UNIVERSO EN EXPANSIÓN (From the Quantum World to the Expanding Universe) from Shahen Hacyan, and HOYOS NEGROS Y LA CURVATURA DEL ESPACIO-TIEMPO (Black Holes and the Curvature of Space-Time) also from the same author (FCE, México), to read a well-written, general level book about Quantum Theory, Inflationary Theory, Black Holes and Wormholes (they are written in Spanish, though). Let's not forget Complex Systems and Chaos Theory, which (many researchers agree :-P) is thought to the third revolution on physics of the twentieth century. This is another problem for determinist theories (for long-term predictions infinite precision is needed in order to avoid chaotic behavior of physical systems)... and our fellow Brian Greene just ignored it on this book.
really good stuff, but if you dont have any science and physics background , you will be lost.. opt for something like einstein for begginers first :o)
A great book which makes understandable that which is almost not understandable.

I like the information from this author's books but I felt the book was being "dumbed down" by using the characters from "The Simpsons" to make his examples.  This family does not watch the show.  Quantum mechanics does not need to be dumbed down for it's readers.

Like his other book An Elegant Universe, Brian Green really gets you invovled in both historical physics and astronomy as well as modern bleeding edge theory.  You don't have to be a PHD to appreciate and understand most of the concepts presented in this book.

Greene writes well, but like a number of science authors he covers much of the same ground here as his last book.  When he isn't talking about superstring theory, he is presenting a general ramble of diverse topics---kind of like a physics 101 class-- that have been covered many times in the popular literature.
A very good read...if you can understand all of it you are a better man than I....but that is part of the fun!

I liked the Elegant Universe and I enjoyed The Fabric of the Cosmos even more. Anyway this thought provoking book cannot answer the big puzzles that heap in my e-mail delivered from space exploration e-zines. It is hard to digest the mysterious intense stars formation in the early universe, the unanticipated location of the quasars in humble homes and the discovery of huge (about 80 times heavier than the sun) stars that orbit each other in just 3.7 days. These brain twisters can find surprisingly elegant clarification in the "firework universe", described by Eugene Savov in his book Theory of Interaction the Simplest Explanation of Everything. This book will make your day if you take some mental effort to understand how the texture of reality is laid bare in it.
the person that got this book for christmas is a fan of the author, so he was very pleased to get this book.
Put the number 0736697500 in the Amazon search bar to bring up  [UNABRIDGED 19 CD SET The Fabric of the Cosmos : Space, Time, and the Texture of Reality

The Elegant Universe is unquestionably brilliant.  This book is a good reminder if you don't want to re-read the Elegant Universe but there's not all that much new here, perhaps because progress in string theory is slow.

This is a good review aftering reading The Elegant Universe: Superstrings, Hidden Dimensions, and the Quest for the Ultimate Theory. If you are new to Greene start with the Elegant Universe and then if you must go on to the The Fabric of the Cosmos
bought it to replace a book I checked out for a friend(who was irresponsible,think I learned my lesson on this one)
The Fabric of the Cosmos is a great book, i could not put it down.

I love this book. I have manage to get through several paragraphs at a time without saying, "Huh?" which is remarkable considering the subject matter.  Sadly, that all changed when I reached p. 369 and a diagram of Calabi-Yau shapes. I happened to be at Denny's at the time, and while my fellow customers only looked me quisically when I turned the book round and round high over my head, they were a little less forgiving when I grasped it between my feet while doing a handstand on the table.  As I saw the waitress dialing 911, I decided this might be a good time to go home and play with my kitty. Continued. . .

Professor Greene is right. String theory really is the best solution to all the problems of physics. He sees it and he allows us to see it too. But there are many good reasons to believe that physics itself will never see it. This is exactly the same situation that Godel exposed in mathematics: we can see what the system itself cannot see. But that's fine because deep down we all know that we are more than our systems.

I am giving a low review not because of the writing, but for the fact there is nothing new here if you have read The Elegant Universe. I dont see why there was a need for this book since no new information about string theory, etc has come since his last book. What a rip!

For someone who is fascinated by the cosmos but has little formal education in this area, this is a lovely book.  Brian Green is a clear, insightful writer.  His prose is dense in that each word is carefully selected.  There is no fluff yet his writing brings great clarity to a complex area of science.  I highly recommend this book to anyone who is wants to know more about this subject but who is not a scientist.

I bought this book after watching the show on the discovery channel. I think the author did a great job of explaining something highly complex in the world of physics, how ever; the mathmatical fomulas in this book are out of my grasp, unless you have a solid college background in mathmatics the formulas will read more like gooble-de-gook..which is unfortunate becuase the concepts of the string theory are based on the formulas. If you are math savy this will be a great read. If you aren't than you may quickly become dissatisfied with the book . It refers to ther formulas through out the book.. good luck, best of reading. Mercy W.

Some interesting and enlightening parts were eventually deadened by monotonous and uninpiring overly-scientific exposition in my audio-version.  Yawn. Too heady and scientific for me. Give me Newtonian physics any day!  Reality was much simpler then.  Of course, alot of the time I am not sure this author, or anyone else for that matter, knows what they are talking about in attempting to describe, mathematically or otherwise, string or superstring theory.  YUK!

Greene is one of the better pop-science writers, but many of the examples he uses are extremely poor and bound to leave the reader even more confused. Any writer who doesn't know how (or when) to capitalize Earth (= the proper name of our planet) and earth (= synonym for dirt or soil) should not be printed in the United States.

Here is how Knopf prints money.  They get a pseudo-physicist to rewrite his first book on philosophy, after he starred in a TV production centered about it.  Long-winded and boring, the wordiness serves to obfuscate the concepts.  Stick to Hawking's Brief History of Time or Einstein's Meaning of Relativity.  This books adds nothing new, and has begun subtracting.  If you're into entertainment and David Duchovney wanna-bes, watch the X-files.

This book its not that it was bad written. I am one of those wholl side with Einstein when it comes to ' is that the way God would do it with Science.' I just didnt feel right going into the Quantum nonsense... If everything was in some sense connected or intervened how could we be individualized? I believe eveything takes a name shape of itself. Quantum physics no matter how hard it strives will nor surpass the entities of God's creation.
